articles.title: About Michael Maniscalco
articles.contents:
Research Interests
I am a PhD candidate studying Marine Science at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Working with Mark Brzezinski and Kimberlee Thamatrakoln to relate community biogeochemistry and phytoplankon physiology to ’Omics measurements. My graduate research has focused on how the presence or absence of abiotic factors such iron, nitrate, silicate, and light impact phytoplankton communities along the California coast. More broadly, I am interested in ways that new and publicly available microbial ’Omics data can be leveraged to answer big questions about evolution, ecology, and ocean processes.
Short History
I grew up in New Jersey, and received my B.S. in Biotechnology at Rutgers New Brunswick The State University of New Jersey. Despite having no background in marine or environmental science, my first introduction to academic laboratory based research was in a marine microbial molecular biology lab. I primarily used a single celled marine protist- Thalassiosira pseudonana- as a model organism without strong connections to marine themes, but a seed if interest was sown about the intriguing ways biomolecules like DNA, RNA, and protein could be used to understand not just physiology but larger earth processes.
After I graduated I moved on to be a laboratory technician and manager at the primarily undergraduate serving institution-Rider University. As a technician my primary research focused on interrogating the expression pattern of a group of circadian clock genes in the haloarchaean Haloferax volcanii. I also had the opportunity to mentor a number of talented undergraduate students and help them develop their scientific acumen through their own independent research.
After 3 years I moved on and started my PhD at UCSB and at that time my advisors and I had a plan for how I would mostly apply low throughput techniques that i was familiar with such as qPCR and Western blotting to learn more about how diatoms create silica frustules, but as is the norm those initial plans didn’t end up panning out. Over the course of my PhD I have shifted to primarily using metatranscriptomic analysis, which has progressed from analyzing datasets prepared by collaborators, to de novo assembling, annotating, and analyzing ’Omic data myself and relating it to disparate metadata to make meaningful interpretations.

articles.title: Stearns Wharf Harmful Algal Bloom Monitoring
articles.contents:
Stearns
Wharf, Santa Barbara Harmful Algal Bloom Monitoring
In addition to my primary research I perform weekly plankton sampling
at Stearns Wharf in Santa Barbara as part of the Southern California
Coastal Ocean Observation System
(SCCOOS) harmful algal bloom
monitoring alert program
(HABMAP).
This serves both the local and broader community in helping to
anticipate, identify, and respond to the presence of large amounts of
harmful algal species in the water. These harmful algal blooms or (HABs)
can produce toxins that accumulate in larger and larger proportions as
they move up the food chain from shellfish to birds or marine mammals. A
large persistent HAB in 2017 has been linked to increased marine mammal
strandings all along the Pacific coast.
Stearns Wharf HAB data
visualization



Shiny App Iframe





Note that the fluorescence based chlorophyll measurements carry a
distinct biofouling signature over intermediate periods of time.
Data availability
All data from Stearns Wharf as well as other shore station is
available through the NOAA
ERDDAP
portal
